summary.p: This manuscript of the Amarakoṣa, or Nāmaliṅgānuśāsana, starts from the beginning of the text and breaks off in the middle of the vanauṣadhivargaḥ of the second kāṇḍa. Apart from the main text, there are at least two hands that have annotated the text, creating a layered commentary.

Take the first verse as an example (folio 1v):
yasya jñānadaẏāsiṃdhor agādhasyānaghā guṇāḥ
sevyatām akṣaẏo dhīrāḥ sa śriye cāmṛtāya ca || 1 ||
One hand, writing in red, has written numbers above the words of the verse, reordering them to show the grammatical structure of the sentence; the number 1 is written above dhīrāḥ, indicating that it should be the beginning of the sentence. The scribe has also added a number of glosses, in the kathaṃbhūtinī style (Tubb & Bo0se 2007, 149ff) to connect the words. If we read the annotations along with the word order suggested by them, the resulting commentary would look like this: he dhīrāḥ | bhavadbhiḥ sevyatām | saḥ kaḥ yasya guṇāḥ anaghāḥ | kathaṃbhūtasya jñānadaẏāsiṃdhoḥ | punaḥ kathaṃbhūtasya agādhasya | kathaṃbhūtaḥ saḥ akṣaẏaḥ | śriye cāmṛtāya ca |
A different hand, writing in black, has added a further gloss on the last pāda of the verse: ca dvayaṃ ubhayoḥ prādhānyadyotanāya
More elaborate versions of this kathaṃbhūtinī commentary can be found in the Ṭīkā of Kṛṣṇamitra as well as in two manuscripts held at DAV college: MS nos. 3347 and 3351.
